hedline.hl2: A Better Way to Burn With Macintosh and Even Use the New Blu-ray Discs

abstract.p: Roxio introduces Toast 8 Titanium, software for Mac computers to record CDs and DVDs, including ability to record data on high-capacity Blu-ray discs; photo (S)

block.p: Most modern Macintosh computers can record CDs and DVDs just fine on their own with software built into the Mac operating system, but third-party programs often add more flexibility.

Roxio's latest software for Mac burners, Toast 8 Titanium, offers about two dozen new or improved features, including the ability to record data on high-capacity Blu-ray discs, LightScribe labeling to make your discs prettier and a file-recovery utility for damaged discs. The software, available from online and offline retailers for about $80, works on Macs with G4, G5 or Intel processors, and requires Mac OS X 10.4.8 or later; full requirements and features are listed at www.roxio.com.

Roxio's latest software for Mac burners, Toast 8 Titanium, offers about two dozen new or improved features, including the ability to record data on high-capacity Blu-ray discs, LightScribe labeling to make your discs prettier and a file-recovery utility for damaged discs. The software, available from online and offline retailers for about $80, works on Macs with G4, G5 or Intel processors, and requires Mac OS X 10.4.8 or later; full requirements and features are listed at www.roxio.com.

Owners of compatible TiVo digital recorders can make use of the included TiVoToGo software, which is finally available for the Macintosh. (Windows users can get their software right from www.tivo.com.) The software is the only TiVo-authorized way for Mac owners to transfer their recorded television programs from their TiVo boxes to DVD and portable video players like the iPod or Sony PlayStation Portable.
